awd_titl_txt: Polylogarithms, Motives,  L-Functions, and Quantum Geometry of Moduli Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns research at the boundary of Number Theory and Algebraic Geometry and extends to several other branches of mathematics. In particular it concerns work on polynomial equations and their solutions. Associated to the solutions of  a collection of polynomial equations is a mathematical object, their zeta function. This research will  investigate a deep collection  of conjectures  concerning these zeta functions, made by  Alexander Beilinson, Don Zagier and others 30-40 years ago. These investigations also have consequences for theoretical Physics.  Another aspect of the project is that it will support the training of graduate students in this area of research.

Any system of polynomial equations  with integral coefficients gives rise to a  function of one complex variable,  the Zeta Function Z(s). It  encodes in a very mysterious way the most important characteristics of the space of solutions.  In particular,  the special values of the zeta function Z(s) at the integral values of  s should be expressed as periods, that is integrals of certain specific type. The PI is going to study the special values of the zeta functions, relating them  to the very classical mathematical objects, going back to Euler  - the classical polylogarithm functions, which generalize the logarithm function. The technique  the PI is using came from  several  parts of Mathematics and Mathematical Physics, such as the theory of motives, algebraic K-theory on one hand, and cluster varieties and their quantization on the other. The very existence of deep connections between polylogarithms and cluster varieties is surprising. It will have many applications far beyond Algebraic Geometry and Number Theory, e.g. in the investigation of Scattering Amplitudes in Theoretical Physics. The PI will continue his work on  quantum geometry of various moduli spaces and their applications in Algebraic Geometry, Mathematical Physics and Number Theory, including  the study of classical and quantum polylogarithms, special values of L-functions,  motivic Galois groups,  Quantum Hodge Field Theory, cluster structure and quantization of   moduli spaces of local systems. The main priorities of the project are the following:
a) To use the  relationship between cluster varieties and polylogarithms to prove Zagier's conjecture on the  special values  of the Dedekind zeta function at least for s=5, and relate the motivic cohomology to the cohomology of the polylogarithmic motivic complexes.  
b) To develop the theory of quantum multiple polylogarithms, providing a quantum deformation of the periods of the prounipotent completion of the motivic  fundamental group of the punctured projective line. 
c) To give a comprehensive treatment of the cluster structure of various moduli related to the moduli spaces of G-local systems on surfaces. Apply this to quantization of these moduli spaces, representation theory of quantum groups,  mirror symmetry and Mathematical Physics. 
d) Develop  Quantum Hodge Field Theory. Its tree level gives a Feynman integral approach to Hodge theory. Derive it as a  Hodge-theoretic analog of Chern-Simons theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Spaces has always been one of the primary objects of study in Mathematics.

Moduli spaces are spaces which parametrise mathematical object of a given kind. They include Grassmannians, Flag varieties, moduli spaces M(g,n) of algebraic curves of a given genus g with n marked points, character varieties - that is moduli spaces of representations of the fundamental group of a topological surface to a group G, aka moduli spaces of flat G-bundles, moduli spaces of vector bundles on an algebraic curve with given topological characteristics, moduli spaces of instantons which appeared first in Physics, etc. The study of moduli spaces plays more and more important role in Mathematics and Theoretical Physics.

During the recent years it become clear that many moduli spaces carry hidden additional features. The current project investigates two of them: the quantization and non-commutative deformation of moduli spaces. Let us start from the latter.

Spaces are often described as solutions of a system of polynomial equations with, say, rational coefficients. Therefore we can consider the sets given by solutions in different fields, like real, complex, or p-adic numbers. The non-commutative spaces produce sets of solutions with values in any non-commutative fields, e.g. quaternions.

Our work with Kontsevich demonstrates that the moduli spaces of flat vector bundles over decorated topological surfaces are shadows of non-commutative moduli spaces, which carry a non-commutative cluster Poisson structure, equivariant under the action of the mapping class group of the surface S.

The Riemann-Hilbert correspondence identifies the moduli space of flat connections on a topological surface S with the moduli space of differential equations with regular singularities on a Riemann surface of the topological type S. Moduli spaces of Stokes data is the analog of the former for the moduli spaces of differential equations on Riemann surfaces with arbitrary meromorphic singularities. We proved that moduli spaces of Stokes data admit an upgrade to a non-commutative cluster Poisson space, equivariant under a large symmetry group the wild mapping class group. This is new even in the commutative case.

Let us now turn to the quantum moduli spaces.

The quantization of a space produces a non-commutative deformation of its algebra of functions, depending the Planck constant h. However in general the dependence on h is only formal: one can not evaluate it for a given value of the Planck constant.

The cluster Poisson quantization, developed by V. Fock and myself, provides a non-commutative deformation of any cluster Poisson variety, together with the representation of its quantized algebra of functions in a Hilbert space, equivariant under the action of the cluster symmetry group of the variety.

Our work with Shen proves that, for any split adjoint simple group G, the moduli spaces of flat G-bundles on decorated surfaces, with appropriate boundary data, carries a cluster Poisson structure, and thus can be quantised in the above sense.

After the works of Galois and Einstein, the concept of symmetry played the absolutely fundamental role both in Mathematics and in Physics.

The emerged during the last half century concept of quantum groups is a new incarnation of the concept of symmetry. However the very notion what is quantum symmetry remained elusive, since quantum groups are not groups.

The collection of quantum spaces assigned to arbitrary decorated surfaces together with the gluing maps between them, provide a geometric understanding what the quantum symmetry is. Indeed, in the special case when the decorated surface is a punctured disc with two marked points on the boundary, the cluster quantization delivers the Drinfeld-Jimbo quantum group associated with G, together with its principal series of representations. The quantum group coproduct comes as a description of the quantum gluing maps. The collection of all quantum spaces assigned to decorated surfaces and G, together with the gluing maps, is an algebraic-geometric avatar of a Topological Quantum Field Theory (TQFT). It explains geometrically what is the quantum symmetry.

Another application of the cluster structure of moduli space of G-local systems on surfaces is the construction of the second universal motivic Chern class with values in the weight two motivic cohomology in our wotk with Kislinski. This construction has many applications, such as an explicit construction of Ksc Moody group, explicit construction of the line bundle on the moduli space of G-bundles on a given curve generatin the Picard group, etc.

Our work with Fock developes, in the case when the Planck constant h is rational, the cluster geometric quantization of cluster Poisson varieties. It delivers an analytic vector bundle over the generic points of the cluster variety, equivariant under the action of the cluster group of symmetries. hjis leads to new quantum invariants of threefolds fibered over the circle, as well as a new TQFT like structure related to the finite dimensional representations of the De Concini Kac quantum group at roots of unity.
